sense.name: agitate the air to stir up activity (as if) with a fan
sense.commentary: Includes FAN THE FLAMES, FAN THE FIRES Syntax Is: NP1[agent] FAN NP2[patient]
sense.examples: How texts fanned the flames of Ivy fraud. We fanned the fire to help it grow. Jean fanned the smoke away from her, choking. The heat was immense and we fanned ourselves frantically to cool off.

sense.name: make an emotion or quality grow or become stronger
sense.commentary: Syntax Includes: NP1[stimulus] FAN NP2[patient[abstract]] NP1[agent] FAN NP2[patient[abstract]]
sense.examples: This conduct fanned the excitement of the populace. The busboy's insolence only fanned her anger. Madonna says the news media fanned the controversy over her attempts to adopt a boy from Malawi. The electronic media fanned the violence.

sense.name: spread out like a fan
sense.examples: The dealer fanned the cards. She fanned her fingers wide and placed her hands on the table. The peacock fanned its feathers in a glorious display.

sense.name: BASEBALL: strike out a batter
sense.examples: Springer, who fanned the side in the second inning, threw 82 pitches.
